qas.question: How many types of X.25 networks were there originally

answers.text: There were two kinds of X.25 networks. Some such as DATAPAC and TRANSPAC
DATAPAC was developed by Bell Northern Research

qas.question: WHat did foreign clones of DATAPAC allow for

answers.text: A user or host could call a host on a foreign network by including the DNIC of the remote network as part of the destination address
the interconnection of national X.25 networks

qas.question: What was implemented with an X.25 interface?
What was sold to foreign PTTs?

plausible_answers.text: call a host on a foreign network

qas.question: DNIC allowed a host to do what?
The Deutsce Bundespost bought what kind of interface look a likes?
X.25 networks were helped by what?

plausible_answers.text: modified to provide a X.25 host interface in addition to older host connection schemes

qas.question: How were TRANSPAC and TYMNET modified?

plausible_answers.text: a joint venture of Bell Canada (a common carrier) and Northern Telecom (a telecommunications equipment supplier)

qas.question: Bell Northern Research developed TRANSPAC as a joint venture between which two companies?

plausible_answers.text: to foreign PTTs including the Deutsche Bundespost

qas.question: Who did Northen Telecom sell TRANSPAC clones to?

plausible_answers.text: implemented with an X.25 external interface

qas.question: TELENET and TRANSPAC were implemented with what?

plausible_answers.text: allowed the interconnection of national X.25 networks

qas.question: X.25 and X.121 allowed what to happen?
